facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1950 is against the judgment and decree dated 28th February 1946 of the High Court of Judicature at Lahore in Regular Second Appeal No. 887 of 1942.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Appeal  Civil Appeal No. 31 of 1950  against a judgment and decree dated 28th February, 1946, of the High Court of Judicature at Lahore in Regular Second Appeal No. 887 of/942.

facts.text: The plaintiff Arjan Singh alias Puran brought a suit in the court of the Subordinate Judge Jullundur against Inder Singh Kartar Singh and five others.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff, Arjan Singh alias Puran, brought a suit in the companyrt of the Subordinate Judge, Jullundur, against Inder Singh, Kartar Singh and five oth- ers,

facts.text: The suit sought declaration that a will executed by Inder Singh in favour of Kartar Singh about 14 years ago was null and void as against the plaintiff who was Inder Singh's reversionary heir.

anchor.surface_text: for a declaration that a will executed by the first defendant, Inder Singh, in favour of the second defendant, Kartar Singh, about 14 years ago was null and void as against the plaintiff, who was the first defendants rever- sionary heir after his death.

facts.text: The suit comprised a half share of land measuring 395 kanals in village Kadduwal another half share of 837 kanals 11 marlas in village Pattar Kalan and four houses in Pattar Kalan.

anchor.surface_text: The plaint companyprised a half share of land measuring 395 kanals in the village of Kadduw- al, another half share of land measuring 837 kanals and 11 marlas in the village of Pattar Kalan, and four houses in the latter village.

facts.text: In the pedigree plaintiff claims Sehja Singh as his 4th ancestor Jodha Singh and Jai Singh as Sehja Singh's sons and Inder Singh as Jodha Singh's grandson.

anchor.surface_text: In the pedigree attached to the plaint showing the relationship of the parties, the plaintiff claims Sehja Singh as his 4th ancestor. Jodha Singh and Jai Singh are shown as Sehja Singhs sons. Defendant No. 1, Inder Singh, is Jodha Singhs grandson.

facts.text: Parties are Jat agriculturists governed by customary law in matters of alienation of ancestral property and succession.

anchor.surface_text: It is alleged that the parties are Jar agriculturists governed by the customary law in matters of alienation of ancestral property and succession, and that as a sonless proprietor under this law is number companypetent to make a will

facts.text: Sonless proprietor incompetent to make will of ancestral property when collaterals up to 5th degree exist.

anchor.surface_text: to make a will in respect of his ancestral property, when there are companylaterals up to the 5th degree, and as the entire property mentioned in the plaint was ancestral,

facts.text: Plaintiff was born on 22nd July 1919 and was a minor when the will was made.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiff was born on 22nd July, 1919, and was a minor when the will was made, and so the suit was within time.

facts.text: Suit contested mainly by second defendant Kartar Singh who set up his adoption and pleaded properties not ancestral as regards plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was companytested mainly by the second defendant, Kartar Singh, who set up his adoption, and pleaded that the properties were number at all ancestral as regards the plain- tiff.

facts.text: At trial it was admitted that land in Kadduwal was not proved to be ancestral.

anchor.surface_text: At the trial, it was admitted that the land situated in Kadduwal was number proved to be ancestral.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held land in Pattar Kalan not shown to be ancestral because Sehja Singh had three sons Jodha Jai and Pohlo.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge held that even the land in Pattar Kalan was number shown to be ancestral by the evidence adduced on the side of plaintiff, as it was found that the companymon ancestor, Sehja Singh, had number only two sons called Jodha Singh and Jai Singh, but a third son named Pohlo,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge found findings in favour of plaintiff on adoption and limitation but held plaintiff had no locus standi to contest adoption as limitation expired before his birth.

anchor.surface_text: He recorded findings in favour of the plaintiff on the issues as to adoption and limitation, but he also held that the plaintiff had numberlocus standi to companytest the validity of the adoption as the period of limitation had expired long before he was born.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Plaintiff appealed to District Judge and filed application under Order XLI rule 27 and s151 CPC for additional evidence: kami beshi statement Mauza Pattar Kalan stating Pohlo gave up interest.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff preferred an appeal to the companyrt of the District Judge. He filed an application under Order XLI, rule27, and section 151, Civil Procedure Code, for leave to adduce additional evidence. The document he wanted to be taken on record and companysidered, and of which it was alleged that he was number aware at the trial, was a kami beshi statement relating to Mauza Pattar Kalam, which companytained a numbere that the third son, Pohlo, gave up his interest in the ancestral property in favour of his brothers.

facts.text: District Judge allowed additional evidence application on 17th March 1942 before hearing appeal.

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th March 1942, that is, even before he heard the appeal, the District Judge allowed the applica- tion.

facts.text: Additional evidence: naqsha kami beshi prepared 1849-50 and muntakhib asami-war 1852 stating Pohlo relinquished share.

anchor.surface_text: Referring to the two entries found in the naqsha kami beshi prepared in 1849-50 and the muntakhib asami-war pre- pared in 1852, which stated that Pohlo had relinquished his ancestral share,

facts.text: Two witnesses examined for appellant: Munshi Pirthi Nath brought record of rights Pattar Kalan 1849-50; Munshi Niaz Ahmad brought muntakhib asami-war.

anchor.surface_text: Two witnesses were examined on the side of the appellant. Munshi Pirthi Nath is the clerk in the D.Cs office, Jullundur City, and he brought the record of rights for the village Pattar Kalan prepared at the time of the settlement of 1849-50. Munshi Niaz Ahmad is the office Qanungo in the Jullundur Tahsil and he brought the rauntakhib asami-war of the record of rights preserved at the Tahsil Office.

facts.text: District Judge reversed Subordinate Judge decreed plaintiffs suit holding entries genuine Pohlo relinquished share land ancestral qua plaintiff suit within time adoption not true custom does not permit will.

anchor.surface_text: The District Judge reversed the decision of the Subordi- nate Judge and decreed the plaintiffs suit on the strength of this additional evidence. He held that the entries relied on for the appellant were genuine and number forged and that as Pohlo had relinquished his share, the land in Manza Pattar Kalan was ancestral qua the plaintiff.

facts.text: District Judge appeal heard on 24th April 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was heard on 24th April, 1942.

facts.text: High Court held no proof land Pattar Kalan ancestral District Judge not justified admitting additional evidence entries interpolation.

anchor.surface_text: Kartar Singh, the second defendant, took the matter on second appeal to the High Court. The learned Judges of the High Court held that there was numberhing to show that the land in Pattar Kalan was ancestral and that the District Judge was number justified in admitting additional evidence in the shape of the nabsha kami beshi and the muntakhib asami-war records.

facts.text: High Court dismissed suit under s7 Act II 1920 no person can contest alienation of non-ancestral property contrary to custom.

anchor.surface_text: They came to the companyclusion, therefore, that the entire land situated in Pattar Kalan was also number-ancestral and that the suit should have been dismissed in toto, inasmuch as under section 7 of Act II of 1920, numberperson is empowered to companytest any alienation of number-ancestral immoveable property on the ground that such alienation is companytrary to custom.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 2 1951 by CHANDRASEKHARA AIYAR J.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. March 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by CHANDRASEKHARA AIYAR J.

facts.text: Supreme Court held District Judge not justified admitting additional evidence under Order XLI r27 as no lacuna in record.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, the learned Judges of the High Court were right in holding that the District Judge was number justified in admitting this evidence under Order XLI, rule 27.

facts.text: Entries in naqsha kami beshi and muntakhib asami-war regarding Pohlo are subsequent interpolation different pen ink awkward insertion.

anchor.surface_text: Even a superficial observation of the original docu- ments leads one irresistibly to the companyclusion that this entry was a subsequent interpolation. In naqsha kami beshi there was alrerady a remark in that companyumn and the remark relied upon which has very awkwardly been inserted there is with a different pen and in a different ink.

facts.text: No evidence common ancestor Sehja Singh owned Pattar Kalan properties entered in names of two sons equal shares nothing about third son Pohlo or fourth son Hamira.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberhing to show that the companymon ancestor Sehja Singh was possessed of the Mauza Pattar Kalan properties which are found subsequently entered in the name of two sons in equal shares, with numberhing said about the share of the third son Pholo. As a matter of fact, the pedigree table shows that there was a fourth son called Hamira.

He filed an application under Order XLI, rule27, and section 151, Civil Procedure Code, for leave to adduce additional evidence. The document he wanted to be taken on record and considered, and of which it was alleged that he was not aware at the trial, was a kami beshi statement relating to Mauza Pattar Kalam, which contained a note that the third son, Pohlo, gave up his interest in the ancestral property in favour of his brothers.

He filed an application under Order XLI, rule27, and section 151, Civil Procedure Code, for leave to adduce additional evidence. The document he wanted to be taken on record and considered, and of which it was alleged that he was not aware at the trial, was a kami beshi statement relating to Mauza Pattar Kalam, which contained a note that the third son, Pohlo, gave up his interest in the ancestral property in favour of his brothers. A copy of the statement was filed along with the appeal memorandum.

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th March 1942, that is, even before he heard the appeal, the District Judge allowed the application. Referring to the two entries found in the naqsha kami beshi prepared in 1849-50 and the muntakhib asami-war prepared in 1852, which stated that Pohlo had relinquished his ancestral share, he observed These two entries taken together, if found genuine, would enable the Court to arrive at a just conclusion. It is, therefore, in the interest of justice that the additional evidence should be let in. I have taken action under Order XLI, rule 27  1   b , of the Civil Procedure Code.

concepts.unlisted_description: Substantial question of law in second appeal

anchor.surface_text: The discretion to receive and admit additional evidence is not an arbitrary one, but is a judicial one circumscribed by the limitations specified in Order XLI, rule 27, of the Civil Procedure Code. If the additional evidence was allowed to be adduced contrary to the principles governing the reception of such evidence, it would be a case of improper exercise of discretion. and the additional evidence so brought on the record will have to be ignored and the case decided as if it was non-existent. Under Order XLI, rule 27, it is the appellate court that must require the evidence to enable it to pronounce judgment. As laid down by the Privy Council in the well-known case of Kessowji Issur v.G. I. P. Railway 1  the legitimate occasion for the application of the present rule is when on examining the evidence as it stands, some inherent lacuna or defect becomes apparent, not where a discovery is made, outside the court, of fresh evidence and they reiterated this view in stronger terms even in the later case of Parsotim v. Lal Mohan  2 . The true test, therefore, is whether the appellate court is able to pronounce

anchor.surface_text: The discretion to receive and admit additional evidence is not an arbitrary one, but is a judicial one circumscribed by the limitations specified in Order XLI, rule 27, of the Civil Procedure Code. If the additional evidence was allowed to be adduced contrary to the princi- ples governing the reception of such evidence, it would be a case of improper exercise of discretion. and the additional evidence so brought on the record will have to be ignored and the case decided as if it was non-existent. Under Order XLI, rule 27, it is the appellate court that must require the evidence to enable it to pronounce judgment.

holdings.text: The discretion to receive and admit additional evidence under Order XLI rule 27 CPC is not arbitrary but judicial, circumscribed by the limitations in the rule; legitimate only when inherent lacuna or defect apparent after examining evidence as it stands, to enable pronouncement of judgment; not for fresh evidence discovered outside.

anchor.surface_text: There is, however, a fallacy underly- ing this argument. The discretion to receive and admit additional evidence is number an arbitrary one, but is a judi- cial one circumscribed by the limitations specified in Order XLI, rule 27, of the Civil

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council precedents in Kessowji Issur v. G.I.P. Railway and Parsotim v. Lal Mohan; true test is whether appellate court can pronounce judgment on existing materials.

holdings.text: If additional evidence admitted contrary to principles of Order XLI rule 27, it is improper exercise of discretion; such evidence must be ignored and case decided without it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Improper admission vitiates; appellate court must ignore to decide on original record.

holdings.text: District Judge was not justified in admitting additional evidence under Order XLI rule 27 as no inherent lacuna or defect in record; evidence admitted before examining trial record or hearing appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances, the learned Judges of the High Court were right in holding that the District Judge was number justified in admitting this evidence under Order XLI, rule 27.

holdings.reasoning_summary: DJ ordered admission on 17 March 1942 before hearing appeal on 24 April 1942; no finding of lacuna after review.

holdings.text: Entries in naqsha kami beshi and muntakhib asami-war regarding Pohlo relinquishing share are subsequent interpolations, not genuine (different pen, ink, awkward insertion, illegible, inconsistent).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Superficial observation of originals shows interpolation; custody alone insufficient; agrees with High Court detailed critique.

holdings.text: District Judge's finding that entries genuine cannot be conclusive in second appeal as based on improperly admitted evidence and ignores intrinsic defects raising doubts on genuineness.

anchor.surface_text: It is numberdoubt true that a finding of fact, however erroneous, cannot be challenged in a second appeal, but a finding reached on the basis of additional evidence which ought number to have been admitted and without

holdings.reasoning_summary: Erroneous fact finding final under s100 CPC only if proper; here vitiated by procedural error and non-consideration of defects.

holdings.text: No evidence common ancestor Sehja Singh owned Pattar Kalan land; mere entry in equal shares of two sons insufficient to presume ancestral when third (and fourth) son exists with no share mentioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof of ownership by ancestor or inheritance to sons; equal shares of two sons rebutted by third son's existence without explanation.

holdings.text: High Court rightly held land in Pattar Kalan non-ancestral; suit liable to dismissal under section 7 Act II 1920 as no person can contest alienation of non-ancestral immovable property contrary to custom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court; plaintiff reversioner cannot challenge will of non-ancestral property on custom prohibiting wills.

precedents.cited_proposition: legitimate occasion for the application of Order XLI rule 27 is when on examining the evidence as it stands, some inherent lacuna or defect becomes apparent, not where a discovery is made outside the court of fresh evidence
precedents.cited_holding: the legitimate occasion for the application of the present rule is when on examining the evidence as it stands, some inherent lacuna or defect becomes apparent, not where a discovery is made, outside the court, of fresh evidence and the application is made to import it

precedents.citation: Parsotim v. Lal Mohan 58 I. A. 254
